title: Lowry Hill, Minneapolis
marks:
Signature, Date and Inscription

On verso: [Look LR in black: [Alex Fournier July 1888]
text: St. Paul native Alexis Jean Fournier painted a series of six views of Minneapolis in the summer of 1888; three of which, including this view of Lowry Hill, are in the permanent collection. Named after lawyer and railway businessman Thomas Lowry in the late 19th century, the Hill was home to some of the wealthiest people in Minneapolis. Today, two major interstate highways act as boundaries to the north and west of the Hill and some homes built in Fournierâ€™s time still stand today.
provenance:
(Possibly Beard Art Galleries, Minneapolis, Minnesota). Gordon Bates, Minneapolis, Minnesota;[1] purchased by MIA in 1950.

[1] Gordon Bates was the brother of Edmund E. Bates, who also owned works by Fournier in the MIA collection (see 'Farnham's Mill at St. Anthony Falls, Minneapolis', 44.23). In the Edmund Bates correspondence, he mentions that his brother Gordon owns four or five similar 'Minneapolis' pictures by Fournier. A note on the registrar object card states that the painting was purchased in Louisville, Kentucky.
